text:
(1)
Washington Square North, east from Macdougal Street (Washington Square West). The building on the N.E. corner is the Richmond Hill, an apartment house built about 1900 on the site of two old houses. In the background rises the new apartment build- ing at 1 University Place. November 19, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same view, a little over two years later, and from a little nearer to Washington Square, so that part of the One Fifth Avenue apartment house shows over the roof of 26 Washington Square North, adjoining the Richmond Hill. Washington Square North is geographically a part of Waverly Place (q.v.), but was set apart and given its own house numbers early in the 1850's.
February 24, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - MacDougal Street

text:
(1)
Washington Square North, east from Macdougal Street (Washington Square West). The building on the N.E. corner is the Richmond Hill, an apartment house built about 1900 on the site of two old houses. In the background rises the new apartment build- ing at 1 University Place. November 19, 1930.

title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - MacDougal Street

text:
Macdougal Street, east side, the last block, from Washington Square North (Waverly Place) to 8th Street. One of Greenwich Village's outdoor art exhibitions is going on; paintings and drawings are hung on the fence along the side of The Richmond Hill, the seven-story apartment house (about 1895) at 28-27 Washington Square North. Opposite the head of Macdougal Street may be seen Nos. 29, 31, 33 West 8th Street.

May 1, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: MacDougal Street - Washington Square North

text:
108-112 Waverly Place, south side, east of Washington Square West.
May 5, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Waverly Place - Washington Square West: 108-112 Waverly Place, south side, east of Washington Square West.

text:
MacDougal Street, west side, north from Waverly Place, to West 8th Street. The view shows a portion of the Outdoor Art Exhibit.

June 2, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Artists and poets - Greenwich Village.

text:
28-17 Washington Square North, from Macdougal Street towards Fifth Avenue, seen across the N.W. corner of the Square. 27-8, the Richmond Hill, on the corner of Macdougal Street, was built around 1900 on the site of two old private houses.
In the background may be seen the Metropolitan tower, at Madison Avenue and 24th Street, and behind it the needle spire of the Chrysler Building at Lexington Avenue and 42nd Street.
August, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - MacDougal Street

text:
Washington Square Park: The band stand in the western portion of the Park. Buildings in the background line the western side of Washington Square West, from Washington Place (left) to Waverly Place (right, not seen).

December 24, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square West - Waverly Place

text:
Washington Square Park: The band stand in the western portion of the Park. Buildings in the background line the western side of Washington Square West, from Washington Place (left) to Waverly Place (right, not seen).

December 24, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square West - Waverly Place

text:
Art Exhibition at MacDougal Street, at the N.W. corner of Waverly Place.

September 26, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Artists and poets - Greenwich Village.
